title: Analysis: ChatGPT is great at what it's designed to do. You're just using it wrong

last_post.content:
Really enjoyed this article. “You’re using it wrong” is almost always an admission that the product is wrong. It’s a mismatch of a products ability and expectations, and that needs a solution on both sides of the screen.

https://www.pbs.org/newshour/science/analysis-chatgpt-is-great-at-what-its-designed-to-do-youre-just-using-it-wrong

Over the next year, I think we’ll see both a) people having better intuition for what LLMs are [not] good at, and b) better expectation setting by OpenAI/builders what the tools should [not] be used for.

title: Myspace loses all content uploaded before 2016

last_post.content:
Reminder that whatever you store on an internet site will one day vanish, even if it's stored on the largest and richest site in the world:

"Myspace, the once mighty social network, has lost every single piece of content uploaded to its site before 2016, including millions of songs, photos and videos with no other home on the internet."

https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2019/mar/18/myspace-loses-all-content-uploaded-before-2016

Please don't rely on internet services to exist forever, they will all disappear eventually.

Try to store copies of important stuff offline if you can. Music, video, photos etc can all be stored locally.

TootSDK is a Swift package for creating apps that interact with Mastodon, Pleroma and other Fediverse APIs.

last_post.content:
"we show that diffusion models memorize individual images from their training data and emit them [...] we extract over a thousand training examples from state-of-the-art models, ranging from photographs of individual people to trademarked company logos [...] our results show that diffusion models are much less private than prior generative models such as GANs, and that mitigating these vulnerabilities may require new advances in privacy-preserving training." #aiEthics

https://arxiv.org/abs/2301.13188

title: Journalistic Lessons for the Algorithmic Age – The Markup

last_post.content:
I’m sad to announce that I am leaving @themarkup to pursue other projects, which I will announce soon.

It was an honor and a privilege to found @themarkup five years ago to create an investigative newsroom that integrated engineers and journalists. We showed the world what journalism could be: math literate, computationally superpowered, and human-centered.

Hace unos años trabajaba de librera en el Reino Unido (seguro que ya lo he comentado en alguna ocasión). Es el trabajo al que más cariño le guardo, por todo lo que me permitió crecer no solo a nivel laboral, sino también personal. Hasta entonces había sido una lectora más que conocía el "mundillo" desde fuera, ignorando todo el esfuerzo que hay detrás (recepciones, devoluciones, clasificaciones, atención al cliente...). También me hizo darme cuenta de las diferencias culturales y de mercado que hay entre un país y otro, y que influyen de forma directa en la venta. Todo ello me llevó a escribir un artículo (Reflexiones de una librera) que fue publicado en la revista Zoozobra. Hace poco se han cumplido cinco años de su publicación, pero encuentro que las cosas no han cambiado demasiado. Por aquí os dejo el enlace por si queréis echarle un vistazo:

📚 http://zoozobra.com/reflexiones-de-una-librera 📚

Interesting article by Michael Berry why special functions are special:
https://physicstoday.scitation.org/doi/10.1063/1.1372098

I remember the fascination when during my master research project I encountered the Lambert W function which arises when you want to invert x•exp(x). It was one of the few cases with an exact solution to some of the properties of a many-body problem (quantum droplets) which are both non-trivial and easy to understand. However, I straggled some days to get some something out of this function.
